chapter.title: Pointers
chapter.para: I got this from: Pointers in C with examples.
A pointer is a variable that points to a section of memory. Below is a program that points to a block of memory to show how we can access memory in C.

sect1.title: Address of Operator
sect1.para: Before we look at pointers, we'll define what we mean by computer memory in address.c.

para.programlisting: Value of var is: 10 Address of var is: 0x7ffd5d20b56c

sect1.para: Thus, in this context the amperstand is the "Address Of" operator.

sect1.title: Value At Address Operator
sect1.para: Use the asterisk to create a pointer to a variable. The following example shows how pointers work, but it's for demonstration purposes only as we either have an address to a variable or a variable, but usually not both. Here's pointer.c:

para.programlisting:
Address of var is: 0x7ffda322535c
Address of var is: 0x7ffda322535c
Address of pointer p is: 0x7ffda3225350
Value of pointer p is: 0x7ffda322535c
Value of var is: 10
Value of var is: 10
Value of var is: 10

sect2.title: What Are Arrays?
sect2.para: I got this from: Pointers in C with examples.
First we'll start by covering arrays. An array is a variable that holds multiple values of the same type. Let's make an array of ints.
Let's make a character array, which is a C string. Note that C will automatically allocate the size of the array for us if we leave the number of elements blank.
We also learn that we can access a C string just like a normal array.
NEXT SHOW HOW WE CAN USE A POINTER TO AN ARRAY TO ACCESS CHARACTERS.

sect2.title: How To Use A Pointer To An Array
sect2.para: Here we demonstrate that pointers are merely indexes into arrays. It also shows that the increment operator will automatically increment the size of the type. That is, an int is different from a double, but if you increment a given type of pointer, it will automatically increment properly. Because of this, in order for this to work, you must know the size of the type at compile time.

sect1.title: Dynamically Allocating Memory I (Malloc and Free)
sect1.para: In C (and in any programming language) each variable uses memory. C is unique in that it's one of the few langauges which exposes some of the details of this proceess.
In this example, we're going to create an array, but we don't know at compile time how large to make it.
Note, one can modify ARRAY_SIZE and allocate and zero different amounts of memory.
